title: Docker Essentials
description: Learn core Docker concepts including containers, images, volumes, networks, and best practices.

cards.front: What's the key difference between containers and VMs?
cards.back: Containers share the host OS kernel and isolate at the process level, making them lightweight and fast to start. VMs include a full OS copy and hardware virtualization, consuming more resources.
A Docker image is a read-only template containing the application code, runtime, libraries, and dependencies. Images are built from Dockerfiles and stored in registries.
A container is a runnable instance of an image. It includes the application and its dependencies, isolated from other containers and the host system.
A Dockerfile is a text file containing instructions to build a Docker image. It defines the base image, commands to run, files to copy, and configuration settings.
A volume is a persistent data storage mechanism managed by Docker. Unlike bind mounts, volumes work across different systems and are the preferred way to persist data.
A Docker network allows containers to communicate with each other and external systems. Docker provides bridge, host, overlay, and none network drivers.
Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container applications using a YAML file. It simplifies orchestrating multiple services, networks, and volumes.
Docker caches each instruction in a Dockerfile as a layer. If a layer hasn't changed, Docker reuses the cached version, speeding up builds. Order matters for optimal caching.
Multi-stage builds use multiple FROM statements in a Dockerfile. You can copy artifacts from earlier stages to later ones, creating smaller final images by excluding build tools.
A Docker registry stores and distributes Docker images. Docker Hub is the public registry, but you can run private registries for internal images.

cards.front: What's the difference between ENTRYPOINT and CMD?
cards.back: ENTRYPOINT defines the executable that runs when the container starts. CMD provides default arguments for ENTRYPOINT or the command to run if ENTRYPOINT isn't set.
HEALTHCHECK instruction tells Docker how to test if a container is working correctly. It runs a command periodically and marks the container as healthy or unhealthy.
A bind mount links a host directory or file into a container. Unlike volumes, bind mounts depend on the host's filesystem structure and aren't managed by Docker.

cards.front: What are key Docker security best practices?
cards.back: Run as non-root user, use specific image tags (not 'latest'), scan images for vulnerabilities, minimize image layers, and follow the principle of least privilege.
'docker exec' runs a command in a running container. Commonly used with -it flags to open an interactive shell for debugging or maintenance tasks.
